message.content:
<<<api>>>: SortedMap.firstKey
<<<code>>>:  TreeMap<Date, String> policyMap = new TreeMap<Date, String>();
    Calendar cal = Calendar.getInstance();
    policyMap.put(addDate(cal, 2).getTime(), "Amount is 10");
    policyMap.put(addDate(cal, 10).getTime(), "Amount is 10");
    policyMap.put(addDate(cal, -10).getTime(), "Amount is -10");
    policyMap.put(addDate(cal, 11).getTime(), "Amount is 11");
    policyMap.put(addDate(cal, -11).getTime(), "Amount is -11");
    policyMap.put(addDate(cal, -12).getTime(), "Amount is -12");
    Iterator<Date> iter = policyMap.keySet().iterator();
    while (iter.hasNext()) {
        Date cpDate = iter.next();
        System.out.print("From "+cpDate + " to " + policyMap.get(cpDate));
        if(iter.hasNext()){
            TreeMap<Date, String> policySubMap = new TreeMap<Date, String>(policyMap.tailMap(cpDate));
            policySubMap.remove(policySubMap.firstKey());
            System.out.println(" | amount > " + policySubMap.firstKey());
        }
        else System.out.println("Checking date");
    }

    public Calendar addDate(Calendar cal, int amount) {
        cal.add(Calendar.DATE, amount);
        return cal;
    }
<<<explanation>>>: The code you provided is using the TreeMap correctly. The iterator iterates over the keys in the TreeMap in ascending order, which is the natural order of the keys since you are using Date as the key type. The TreeMap maintains the keys in sorted order, so you don't need to worry about sorting them yourself. The TreeMap.tailMap(cpDate) method returns a view of the map containing only the keys greater than or equal to cpDate, and then you remove the first key from that submap using policySubMap.remove(policySubMap.firstKey()). This effectively removes the smallest key greater than cpDate from the original TreeMap. The TreeMap.firstKey() method returns the smallest key in the map, so you can use it to get the next key without incrementing the iterator's index.
